awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Spin Correlations and Spin-Orbit  Effects in New Quantum Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports collaborative research and educational activities carried out among theory groups at Ohio University and the University of Florida, working in close connection with scientists in Argentina and Brazil, to combine techniques and expertise and tackle important and topical problems in materials research.  The project will focus on exploring electronic properties of materials where the electron's spin degree of freedom is strongly affected by their spatial (orbital) motion.  The coupling of spin and orbital degrees of freedom is a recently rediscovered phenomenon that has been observed to impact a number of properties in metals, semiconductors, and insulators, and can be enhanced by applied electric fields.  The research to be carried out is designed to provide a widely applicable description of how spin-orbit interactions compete with repulsive electron-electron interactions under different external fields and microscopic environments.  This description will be applied to decorated or intercalated graphene (a two-dimensional material made of carbon atoms that is one atom thick), other two-dimensional single crystals, and three-dimensional materials in which the energy of the electronic excitations is linearly proportional to their momentum.  The project is expected to provide fundamental insights into the consequences of spin-orbit interactions as well as to advance the understanding of materials for better experimental characterization and eventual device applications in magnetism, spin-sensitive electronics, and quantum information processing.  The project team also plans a number of educational activities across its different sites, including the training of junior researchers in the US and Latin America, as well as outreach efforts that bring in writers to produce engaging books for a general K-12 audience on topics related to the research.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award will support theoretical research and educational activities aimed at achieving a fundamental understanding of spin-orbit interactions and their competition with Coulomb repulsion in recently discovered materials that include graphene and its derivatives, two-dimensional dichalcogenides and Kagome crystals, three-dimensional Dirac semimetals, and their heterostructures.  In addition to their fascinating and somewhat exotic physical properties, these materials promise a variety of exciting technological applications, from magnetics and spintronics to new carbon-based devices, and even quantum information processing. The project team plans to employ and further develop appropriate theoretical techniques, including the numerical renormalization group, the density-matrix renormalization group, and continuous and tight-binding scattering-matrix approaches, as well as field-theoretical representations of low-energy effective Hamiltonians for the systems of interest. These approaches are proven and reliable in treating strongly correlated problems, and their complementarity gives the collaboration a unique advantage.  The research team consisting of theory groups at Ohio University and the University of Florida, working in close collaboration with scientists in Argentina and Brazil, will seek to advance the techniques to enhance their range of applicability, especially in connection with time-dependent and non-equilibrium phenomena.  Competition between phases of matter, and their control and modification through external probes, are the two main issues to be investigated. A particular focus will be on understanding and guiding experimental developments, with the goal of elucidating the role that intrinsic quantum symmetries play in the presence of external electromagnetic and strain fields.  The project team also plans a number of educational activities across its different sites, including the training of junior researchers in the US and Latin America, as well as outreach efforts that bring in writers to produce engaging books for a general K-12 audience on topics related to the research.

por.por_cntn:
The project “Collaborative Research: Spin correlations and spin-orbit effects in new quantum materials” was carried out from September 2015 until August 2018.  Over this 3-year period, the sustained efforts of the PI’s at both institutions (U Florida and Ohio U), and the dedication and enthusiasm of participating students and postdoctoral researchers, resulted in numerous and significant outcomes: 1) Intellectual outcomes, with key developments in scientific topics, include publications and professional presentations; and 2) Educational outcomes, including a number of graduate and undergraduate student participants that have developed into aspiring young scientists, as well as outstanding student writers on science dissemination topics, and the ongoing science teacher training activities jointly with the Patton College of Education at Ohio University.

In addition to the two US institutions, the joint research established scientific collaborations with colleagues in academic institutions in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Germany and Mexico (involving several student exchanges), that greatly contributed to the successful outcomes achieved during the granting period.

Intellectually, the research was aimed at advancing the understanding of the role played by local environments and time dependent effects on the electronic properties of newly discovered quantum materials, an area of high scientific and technologic interest.  The project focused on materials like graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides, with high potential for device applications, and on the identification of phenomena involving strong electron-electron interactions. Theoretical efforts addressed the effects on electronic and magnetic properties of material systems, introduced by juxtaposing different materials, mechanical deformations, time-dependent mechanical and optical driving, and conditions for the appearance of novel magnetic phases, among other topics.

Our studies revealed the importance of crystal symmetries and relativistic effects giving rise to spin-orbit interactions that entangle the electron spin (the quintessential magnetic property) with its orbital motion as it moves through the crystal. From our studies on mechanical deformations on mono-layer membranes for example, we learned how mechanical perturbations can modify the electric charge distribution in a reversible manner, or affect the adsorption of molecules, making possible to use the same material either as an insulator or as a conductor. We also discovered peculiar one-dimensional states existing at the borders or interfaces of some of these new materials. Several of these theoretical predictions have been confirmed by experiments carried by different groups on various settings.

In parallel to these studies on specific materials, we also carried out extensive analysis on theoretical descriptions for different phases taking place in systems with strong electron-electron correlations that involve entanglement phenomena. A particular example is the thorough examination of quantum impurity models in which we revealed specific signatures of entanglement effects between the impurities and its environment. We also produced a full description of magnetic interactions within various mono-layer materials and heterostructures including mono-layer, bilayer graphene and dichalcogenide materials. 

Results have been widely disseminated in numerous high-level scientific journals such as Physical Review Letters, Physical Review B Rapid Communications, Nano Letters and Nature Communications.  In total, there have been over 35 reports submitted for publication (25 already published), and over 30 presentations (many by students and postdocs) at scientific conferences and workshops.

One of the most important aspects of the project was the education and training of future scientists who were integrated into research projects since the beginning.  Undergraduates and graduate students presented results at various scientific venues and authored papers while working in a highly collaborative environment. Several participating graduate students completed their thesis projects during the duration of this award. And perhaps most importantly, they gained real-world experience on the international nature of science. Currently, several former students hold postdoctoral and professor positions at institutions in the USA and abroad.

The project was also successful in the generation of activities that enhanced science education for the general public. As part of these activities, a collaboration with the Patton College of Education at Ohio University was established with the purpose of developing master level-courses for science teacher candidates and implementation of workshops for training of elementary and middle school teachers. Results of these activities were the topic of a presentation given at the Science Education Council of Ohio Conference.

During the granting period we also offered internships for students in the School of Journalism, interested in pursuing science writing.  In this program students with no or minimal science background produce science articles for a biannual newsletter mailed to colleagues and interested parties all over the world, as well as maintain a website with latest research news. In addition to these activities, we organized diverse outreach events including science presentations at elementary schools, workshops for mid-to high-school girls in the Southeastern Ohio region and visits to the Florida State legislature.
